summary: The document comprises records associated with the Assassination Records Review Board, detailing staff payroll records for Dan L. Hardway, a researcher for the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA). It encompasses payroll authorizations, reasons for document postponements, and the historical value of these records. Additionally, it discusses the classification and restrictions of the records, along with a memorandum about new research employees.
key_findings: The Review Board opted to postpone sections of the records to address privacy issues, notably the redaction of Social Security numbers.
It sheds light on the payroll authorization procedure for committee staff within the U.S. House of Representatives, covering salary adjustments and appointments.
These records are connected to the HSCA's probe into the JFK assassination, underscoring their historical relevance.
A memorandum from July 7, 1977, details the recruitment of four new researchers, including Dan L. Hardway, for the Research/Document Unit.
